choices.text: 50 breaths per minute or more

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT suggest a possible severe bacterial infection in a young infant according to the IMNCI criteria? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Axillary temperature of 37.5°C or above 

 

Explanation: 

 

The IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) protocol uses specific clinical criteria to identify young infants with potential severe bacterial infections requiring urgent treatment. An axillary temperature of 37.5°C represents a normal body temperature and falls below the fever threshold of ≥38.0°C, which would indicate infection. A temperature between 36.5°C and 37.5°C is considered normal and would not trigger the "fever" classification in the IMNCI assessment.

 

The WHO IMNCI classification system specifically designates fever as temperature ≥38°C when assessing for possible severe bacterial infection. Without other clinical signs, a temperature of 37.5°C alone would be classified as "no fever" and would not meet criteria for antibiotic therapy or referral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50 breaths per minute or more - This is a danger sign in IMNCI assessment. The age-specific respiratory rate cutoffs (≥60/min for <2 months; ≥50/min for 2-12 months) define fast breathing, which is classified as pneumonia requiring antibiotic therapy or severe pneumonia if accompanied by chest indrawing.

 

Option B. 10 or more skin pustules - This IS considered a sign of possible severe bacterial infection. The IMNCI guidelines classify multiple skin pustules or a large skin infection as requiring systemic antibiotics due to risk of invasive bacterial disease.

 

Option D. Temperature less than 35.5°C - This IS a critical danger sign. Hypothermia in young infants strongly suggests sepsis and represents impaired thermoregulation. IMNCI classifies temperature <35.5°C as a danger sign requiring immediate referral after pre-referral antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In IMNCI assessment, normal temperature (36.5-37.5°C) does not trigger concern for severe bacterial infection, while fast breathing (age-specific rates), multiple skin infections, and hypothermia (<35.5°C) all represent important clinical signs requiring prompt antibiotic therapy and possible referral.

questions.text: In a community, a new disease led to 60 cases occurring in a year. There were 12 deaths in the given year due to the same disease. Calculate the case fatality rate for this new disease. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20%

 

Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is calculated using the formula:

 

  • CFR 
  • In this case: CFR = (12/60) × 100 = 20%
  • CFR is a proportion (not a rate) where numerator is part of denominator
  • It indicates that out of 100 cases of this disease, 20 are likely to die

 

Educational Objective: 

 


 

It is a proportion (not a rate) that indicates the percentage of cases of a disease that result in death.

questions.text: Which form of cutaneous tuberculosis is typically contracted from direct skin inoculation in individuals with good immunity? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis

 

  • Tuberculosis verrusosa cutis (TBVC) is the form of cutaneous tuberculosis that results from direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin of individuals with good immunity. 
  • It is also called "Anatomist's wart" or "Pathologist's wart" because of its occupational association. 
  • TVC presents as an indurated verrucous plaque that develops at the site of inoculation, typically on trauma-prone sites like the extremities. 

 

 

  • Due to the patient's good immunity, this is a paucibacillary form of cutaneous TB where the infection remains localized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scrofuloderma:

 

  • Scrofuloderma is an endogenous form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs through contiguous spread from an underlying tuberculous focus (lymph node, bone, joint) to the overlying skin. 

 

 

  • It is not acquired through direct skin inoculation. 
  • Scrofuloderma is characterized by painless subcutaneous swellings that break down to form discharging sinuses with undermined edges.

 

Option B. Lupus Vulgaris:

 

  • Lupus Vulgaris can occur through both endogenous (hematogenous spread) and, less commonly, exogenous routes, but it typically affects individuals with moderate immunity rather than good immunity. 
  • It presents as a plaque with an active, advancing margin and central scarring. 

 

 

 

  • While it can occasionally be acquired through direct inoculation, it's not the typical presentation in individuals with good immunity, so TBVC is the better option to choose.

 

Option D. Any of the above:

 

  • Only Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis is specifically associated with direct skin inoculation in individuals with good immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis is distinguished as the form of cutaneous TB acquired through exogenous inoculation in individuals with good immunity, presenting as a localized verrucous plaque at trauma-prone sites, particularly on the extremities.

choices.text: Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation

questions.text: Which of the following is an inclusion criterion for the shorter bedaquiline regimen in the treatment of tuberculosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifampicin-resistant but fluoroquinolone-sensitive TB

 

The shorter bedaquiline regimen is specifically designed for treating certain cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis. It is typically indicated in cases of Rifampicin-resistant (RR) tuberculosis or multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis under certain conditions. This regimen is used when the tuberculosis strain is resistant to Rifampicin, but it remains sensitive to fluoroquinolones.

 

Additionally, in cases where there is resistance to Isoniazid (INH), the shorter regimen can be used if the resistance is due to a mutation in either the KatG or inhA gene, but not both.

 

If both mutations are present, or if the TB is severe or extrapulmonary, the shorter regimen is not recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extrapulmonary TB like Tubercular meningitis: The shorter bedaquiline regimen is not indicated for extrapulmonary TB, as it is intended for pulmonary TB only. Extrapulmonary TB often requires a longer and more complex treatment regimen.

 

Option B. Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation: This scenario represents a more complex form of MDR-TB where resistance occurs due to mutations in both the KatG and inhA genes. The presence of both mutations generally excludes the use of the shorter regimen, as a longer and more intensive treatment is required.

 

Option C. Rifampicin-sensitive TB: The shorter bedaquiline regimen is not indicated for Rifampicin-sensitive TB. This regimen is specifically designed for drug-resistant cases, particularly those resistant to Rifampicin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline shorter regimen is indicated for the treatment of -

 

  • Rifampicin-resistant TB (FQ sensitive) or MDR TB
  • INH Resistant TB – due to mutation in either inhA or Kat G gene (NOT BOTH)
  • Pulmonary TB

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room after consuming 8 digoxin tablets. On examination, he was found to be unstable, with a heart rate of 56 beats per minute. An ECG revealed a third-degree heart block. What is the next step in this patient's care? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digoxin Immune Fab

 

For the management of Digoxin toxicity having the features of Bradycardia and a 3rd degree heart block, we need to administer Digibind, which is an antibody against Digoxin. It is also known as Digoxin immune Fab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lidocaine: Lidocaine is used to treat Ventricular Tachycardia or Ventricular Fibrillation.

 

Option C. DC cardioversion: DC cardioversion is used for tachyarrhythmias when pharmacologic treatment fails. It is not used in bradyarrhythmias.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic used for the treatment of GTCS. It can also be used as a class Ib antiarrhythmic drug for the treatment of Digoxin induced Ventricular Tachycardia, or any polymorphic ventricular tachycardia due to QT prolongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The administration of Digoxin Immune Fab is the next step in the management of life-threatening digoxin toxicity, particularly in the presence of bradycardia and third-degree heart block.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Latanoprost is a Prostaglandin, PGF2α analog, that acts in glaucoma by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor and is used as a first line drug in patients with open angle glaucoma. It can be safely used in bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchospasm as a systemic side effect. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option B. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog used for the termination of pregnancy. It is not relevant for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by the presence of mica-like adherent scales? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pityriasis lichenoides chronica

 

  • Pityriasis lichenoides chronica (PLC) is specifically characterized by mica-like adherent scales. 
  • This chronic papulosquamous condition presents with polymorphic eruptions of successive crops of asymptomatic red-brown papules, which are surmounted by a central, adherent mica-like scale. 

 

 

  • These scales have a distinctive shiny, flaky appearance resembling mica mineral. 

 

 

 

  • The lesions of PLC heal with hypopigmentation and commonly affect the trunk and proximal parts of the extremities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis features silvery white, loose, lamellar scales rather than mica-like adherent scales. 

 

 

  • These scales are easily removable and when scraped, demonstrate the Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding spots). 
  • Psoriatic scales are described as micaceous, silvery white, but they are not adherent like those in PLC.

 

Option B. Pityriasis rosea:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is characterized by a collarette of scales on the leading edge of lesions, not mica-like adherent scales. 
  • The scales in pityriasis rosea have their outer edge attached within the active margin of the lesion, while the inner edge remains free (which produces the "hanging curtain sign" when stretched).

 

Option C. Seborrheic dermatitis: 

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis features greasy or yellowish scales rather than mica-like adherent scales. 

 

 

  • These scales are typically found in sebum-rich areas of the body, such as the scalp, face, and flexures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis lichenoides chronica is distinguished by its mica-like adherent scales surmounting red-brown papules, which heal with characteristic hypopigmentation — a key diagnostic feature that differentiates it from other papulosquamous disorders.

questions.text: The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) primarily describes the body's response to which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Stressful situations

 

Explanation: 

 

The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) is a model developed by Hans Selye that describes the body's physiological response to stress. It outlines how the body responds to any demand (stressor) placed upon it, regardless of whether the stressor is physical, psychological, or environmental. The GAS consists of three stages: alarm reaction (fight-or-flight response), resistance (adaptation), and exhaustion. It represents a general biological response to stress rather than being specific to any particular psychiatric condition.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Panic Attacks (Incorrect): While panic attacks involve physiological stress responses, they represent a specific type of anxiety response rather than the general stress response described by GAS. Panic attacks are acute episodes characterized by intense fear and specific physical symptoms like palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath.
  • Option B. Depression (Incorrect): Depression represents a mood disorder with persistent low mood, anhedonia, and other emotional and physical symptoms. While chronic stress can contribute to depression, and there may be HPA axis dysregulation in depression, GAS describes the general stress response rather than the specific pathophysiology of depression.
  • Option C. Anxiety Disorders (Incorrect): Anxiety disorders involve excessive worry, fear, and physiological arousal. While anxiety certainly involves stress response systems, GAS describes the broader physiological response to any stressor, not just anxiety disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) is a fundamental model describing how the body responds physiologically to any type of stressor through three stages: alarm reaction, resistance, and exhaustion. It involves the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and represents a non-specific response to stress rather than being particular to any specific psychiatric condition.

questions.text: Repeated Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) of the brain has been FDA-approved for the treatment of which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Depression

 

Explanation: 

 

Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of major depressive disorder. rTMS uses rapidly changing magnetic fields to produce small electric currents (known as eddy currents) in superficial cortical neurons" and is "approved as a treatment modality in major depressive disorder." It is typically used for patients with depression who have not responded adequately to antidepressant medications.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Resistant Schizophrenia (Incorrect): While there is ongoing research into the potential benefits of rTMS for various symptoms of schizophrenia, it is not FDA-approved for the treatment of resistant schizophrenia. Clozapine remains the standard treatment for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.
  • Option C. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (Incorrect): Deep TMS was approved by the FDA for the treatment of OCD in 2018. At the time this question was written, option C was incorrect; however, as of today, it would also be considered a correct option.
  • Option D. Acute Psychosis (Incorrect): rTMS is not FDA-approved for the treatment of acute psychosis. Antipsychotic medications are the primary treatment for acute psychotic episodes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) is a non-invasive brain stimulation technique that has the FDA approval for the following psychiatric disorders:

  1. Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) 
  2. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) 
  3. Anxious Depression 
  4. Smoking Cessation

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has appreciable shortening in her right leg. She is diagnosed with TB Hip. Her presentation will come under which stage? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage III

 

STAGES OF TUBERCULOSIS OF HIP

 

  • Stage 1: 
    • Stage of synovitis
    • FABER (Flexion, Abduction and External rotation)
    • Lengthening
  • Stage 2: 
    • Stage of early arthritis
    • FADIR (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation) 
    • <1 cm shortening
  • Stage 3: 
    • Stage of advanced arthritis
    • FADIR (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation) 
    • >1 cm shortening
    • Appreciable shortening is a key characteristic.
  • Stage 4: 
    • Stage of subluxation/dislocation
    • Wandering acetabulum or pestle and mortar appearance
  • Stage 5: 
    • Stage of sequelae, ankylosis or severe arthritis

 

 

Wandering acetabulum (actually wandering femur head)

 

 

Additionally,

  • Stage V: Described as a "fused, finished off joint" known as fibrous ankylosis. This stage represents the end progression of certain joint diseases where there is complete fusion of the joint surfaces.
  • In TB affecting peripheral joints, such as the hip and knee, the fusion is more commonly fibrous ankylosis, where the fusion involves more fibrous tissue rather than direct bone fusion. This is painful condition. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I:

  • Known as the stage of synovitis.
  • Characterized by increased capacity of the hip.
  • The position of comfort is FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation).
  • FABER leads to lengthening of the leg, not shortening.

 

Option B. Stage II:

  • Early arthritis stage with joint damage.
  • The lower limb adopts a position of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation.
  • Shortening is present but is > 1 cm and not appreciable.

 

Option D. Stage IV:

  • Involves destruction of the bone and changes in the shape of the joint.
  • The femoral head migrates, causing subluxation or dislocation.
  • Known as the stage of the wandering acetabulum, a misnomer for the wandering femoral head.
  • Not specifically associated with the appreciable shortening described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Stage III of TB hip is characterized by late or advanced arthritis with appreciable shortening of the leg (> 1 cm).

questions.text: Rickets occurs due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin D

 

  • Rickets is a skeletal disorder that results from a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. 
  • The primary cause of rickets is a lack of Vitamin D, which is essential for the absorption of calcium and phosphate in the body. 
  • Without adequate Vitamin D, bones can become soft and weak.
  • Key features of rickets include:
    • Cupping: The metaphyseal ends of bones become cup-shaped.
    • Splaying: An increase in the width of the metaphyseal ends.
    • Flaring: The ends of the bones point outward.

 

 

  • These characteristics are critical diagnostic features of rickets and help differentiate it from other bone disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to issues like night blindness and impaired immunity.

 

Option B. Vitamin B: B vitamins are crucial for energy production and neurological function. 

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which presents with symptoms like bleeding gums and joint pain. In vitamin C deficiency, the bony ends appear more white on radiographs (Whitening).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rickets is primarily caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, which leads to characteristic bone deformities such as cupping, splaying, and flaring of the metaphyseal ends.

questions.text: In a normal distribution for weights of a class of college students, Mean value is 82 kg. The calculated SD is 1.5 kg. Calculate the range of weight for 95% students covering 2 SD. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 79 – 85 kg

 

In a normal distribution:

 

  • Mean ± 2SD covers 95% of all values
  • Formula: Range = Mean ± (2 × SD)
  • Given: Mean = 82 kg, SD = 1.5 kg
  • Therefore: Range = 82 ± (2 × 1.5) = 82 ± 3 = 79 to 85 kg This means 95% of students will have weights between 79 and 85 kg.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a normal distribution:

 

  • Mean ± 1SD includes 68% of values
  • Mean ± 2SD includes 95% of values
  • Mean ± 3SD includes 99.7% of values

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA gyrase inhibition

 

The description of a drug causing tendon rupture and arthropathy, especially in the context of treating a urinary tract infection, points towards a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, work by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are essential for bacterial DNA replication and transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ribosomal Inhibition: Antibiotics that inhibit ribosomes, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides, affect protein synthesis. These drugs are not typically associated with tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Option C. Cell Wall Synthesis Inhibition: Drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis, like beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins) and vancomycin, are not known to cause tendon rupture or arthropathy as a common side effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Folic Acid Synthesis: Antibiotics that inhibit folic acid synthesis, such as sulfonamides and trimethoprim, do not typically cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are associated with serious side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy.

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via increase in cAMP. There are several steps involved in this mechanism as given below. Which of the following is correct sequence of events in cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET May 2024)

 

Steps involved


1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
2. Activation of PKA
3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway is:

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  3. Activation of PKA
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins

 

Therefore, the correct answer is: B. 1, 3, 2 and 4

questions.text: A patient is found on a railway track with hot dry skin, raised temperature, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dhatura poisoning

 

The patient presents with several characteristic signs and symptoms: hot dry skin, raised temperature (hyperthermia), dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and staggering gait. These symptoms are indicative of anticholinergic poisoning, and specifically point towards Dhatura poisoning.

 

Dhatura (Datura) is a plant that contains tropane alkaloids, such as atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which have strong anticholinergic effects.

 

These effects include: (Mnemonic DHATURA)

 

  • Dryness of skin and mucous membranes (due to inhibition of sweat and salivary glands).
  • Hyperthermia (elevated body temperature) because of decreased sweating.
  • Mydriasis (Dilated pupils), leading to photophobia and blurred vision.
  • Agitation
  • Tachycardia.
  • Urinary Retention and loss of accommodation (difficulty focusing).
  • Accommodation loss – Blurred Vision

 

Slurred speech and staggering gait can also be observed due to central nervous system effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alcohol intoxication: While slurred speech and a staggering gait are common in alcohol intoxication, alcohol typically causes hypothermia (lowered body temperature), not hyperthermia. Also, alcohol intoxication generally does not cause hot, dry skin or dilated pupils.

 

Option C. Opioid overdose: This usually presents with pinpoint pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and unconsciousness, not dilated pupils, hyperthermia, or dry skin.

 

Option D. Cocaine poisoning: Cocaine can cause hyperthermia and dilated pupils, but it typically results in increased activity and agitation rather than the slurred speech and staggering gait associated with Dhatura poisoning. Additionally, the dry skin is more characteristic of anticholinergic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dhatura poisoning is characterized by anticholinergic symptoms such as hot dry skin, hyperthermia, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait, distinguishing it from other causes of altered mental status.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: An antiemetic was given to a chemotherapy patient, who then developed symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following medications would have resulted in these symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metoclopramide

 

  • Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and a prokinetic drug that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can be given IV and it can cross the Blood brain barrier, thereby leading to D2 receptor block in the brain which can have side effects like acute dystonia, abnormal movements and drug induced Parkinsonism.
  • In such cases, to treat them, drugs having central anticholinergic action like Benzhexol are used. They work by resorting the balance that has been disrupted by having a relative cholinergic excess in the striatum due to dopaminergic blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ondansetron: Ondansetron is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It is commonly used as an antiemetic, especially in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, but it does not cause extrapyramidal side effects like metoclopramide. Its side effect profile mainly includes headaches, constipation, and QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Meclizine: Meclizine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, used primarily to treat motion sickness and vertigo. It does not block dopamine receptors and therefore does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Scopolamine: Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly motion sickness. It works by blocking acetylcholine receptors and does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms. Its side effects include dry mouth, dizziness, and blurred vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metoclopramide, an antiemetic that acts by blocking D2 receptors, can cause extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors.

questions.text: A patient presents to OPD with history suggestive of tuberculosis. Culture media used commonly in India is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LJ medium

 

In India, Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium has been the traditional and most commonly used culture media for TB diagnosis. According to the transcript, under the National TB Elimination Program (NTEP), two main culture methods are used:

 

  • LJ medium (Lowenstein Jensen medium) - Traditional method
  • Automated liquid culture - Newer method (like Versatrack, BACTEC MGIT 960, BACTALERT)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loeffler medium: Incorrect because. Used primarily for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation

 

Option C. Thayer Martin medium: Incorrect because. This is selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis

 

Option D. Macconkey agar: Incorrect because. Used for differentiating lactose-fermenting from non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacteria

 

Educational Objective:

 

LJ (Lowenstein Jensen) medium is the traditional and commonly used culture media for tuberculosis diagnosis in India, along with newer automated liquid culture systems under NTEP.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an endocrine change associated with protein-energy malnutrition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Low cortisol

 

Explanation: 

 

In protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), the body undergoes specific hormonal adaptations to conserve energy and maintain essential functions. Cortisol, being a stress hormone, actually increases in malnutrition (not decreases). This elevated cortisol helps mobilize amino acids from muscle tissue, stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver, and maintains blood glucose levels during nutritional stress—all critical survival mechanisms during starvation.

The theory of adaptation in malnutrition explains these hormonal changes as the body's attempt to prioritize vital functions while reducing energy expenditure on growth and other non-essential processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low insulin - CORRECT finding in PEM. Insulin secretion decreases to minimize glucose uptake by peripheral tissues and maintain blood glucose for brain function.

 

Option C. Low thyroid hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) decrease, resulting in reduced basal metabolic rate and oxygen consumption as an energy-sparing adaptation.

 

Option D. Elevated growth hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Despite increased growth hormone levels, there is peripheral resistance to its action and decreased production of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), explaining the growth failure despite high GH levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Protein-energy malnutrition produces a characteristic endocrine profile with elevated stress hormones (cortisol), decreased anabolic hormones (insulin, thyroid hormones), and elevated but ineffective growth hormone—all serving to conserve energy and maintain vital functions during nutritional deprivation.

questions.text: A woman at 30 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Which of the following is the most appropriate for this patient for prophylaxis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)

 

During pregnancy, the choice of anticoagulant therapy is crucial due to the risks associated with both the mother and the developing fetus. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is the drug of choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy across all trimesters. It is preferred because it does not cross the placenta, making it safe for the fetus, and it has a lower risk of causing bleeding complications compared to other anticoagulants.

 

In this specific case of a woman at 30 weeks of gestation diagnosed with DVT, LMWH is the most appropriate choice for prophylaxis. Warfarin, although sometimes used in the second trimester, is generally avoided due to its teratogenic effects, particularly during the first trimester and closer to delivery.

 

Newer anticoagulants like Apixaban and Fondaparinux are not typically recommended during pregnancy due to insufficient evidence of safety and potential risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: Warfarin can be used during the second trimester up to 36 weeks if necessary. However, it is typically avoided in pregnancy because it crosses the placenta and can cause fetal complications, especially if used in the first trimester or near term.

 

Option C. Apixaban: Apixaban, a newer oral anticoagulant, is generally avoided in pregnancy due to a lack of sufficient data supporting its safety for the fetus.

 

Option D. Fondaparinux: Although Fondaparinux has a lower risk of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), it is not the first-line choice during pregnancy. The data on its safety in pregnancy are limited, and therefore, LMWH is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for both the treatment and prophylaxis of DVT during pregnancy across all trimesters due to its safety profile for both the mother and fetus.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy involved in drug abuse reports experiencing cross-over of sensory perceptions, where he describes that sounds can be seen and colors can be heard. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this effect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. LSD

 

Explanation: 

 

The phenomenon described is synesthesia (reflex hallucinations), where stimulation in one sensory modality leads to experiences in another sensory modality (e.g., "seeing" sounds or "hearing" colors). This effect is most commonly associated with hallucinogens, particularly LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide).

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Cocaine (Incorrect): Cocaine is a stimulant that primarily causes sympathetic activation (tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis) and euphoria. While cocaine can cause psychotic symptoms like paranoia and tactile hallucinations ("cocaine bugs" or formication), it does not typically cause synesthesia or sensory crossover effects.
  • Option C. Marijuana (Incorrect): While cannabis (marijuana) can also cause synaesthesia or reflex hallucinations, between cannabis & LSD, LSD remains the better answer as these perceptual disturbances are the characteristic feature of hallucinogen intoxication.
  • Option D. PCP (Incorrect): Phencyclidine (PCP) is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause hallucinations, detachment from reality, and severe behavioral disturbances. While it can cause various perceptual disturbances, the specific cross-sensory phenomenon of synesthesia is more characteristic of classical hallucinogens like LSD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Synesthesia (the crossing or merging of sensory modalities) is a characteristic effect of hallucinogenic drugs, particularly LSD. This perceptual phenomenon, where stimuli in one sensory domain trigger experiences in another (like seeing sounds or tasting colors), is part of the profound alterations in consciousness that make LSD and similar substances powerful hallucinogens.

choices.text: Teriparatide can be given along with bisphosphonates.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day
Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a history of Colle's fracture comes to the outpatient department complaining of lower back pain. After undergoing a bone density test, her T score is found to be -2.5. Which of the following statements about the management of her condition is incorrect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

 

This question deals with osteoporotic post-menopausal female, who has a history of fracture as well.

 

Bisphosphonates which act by inhibiting the bone resorption by the osteoclasts form the first line of treatment in this patient. Bisphosphonates are DOC for Osteoporosis (Steroid induced, post-menopausal and due to any reason). These are indicated for 5 years and then a drug holiday of 2-3 years is given to avoid adverse effects (increased risk of bone fractures and osteonecrosis of mandible). These can be repeated for another 5 years after drug holiday.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide can be given along with bisphosphonates: Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone analog that stimulates bone formation by increasing osteoblast activity. It is particularly useful in patients with severe osteoporosis and a history of fractures. It can be started before bisphosphonates in certain cases.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day: The recommended daily intake of calcium for postmenopausal women is around 1200 mg. This helps maintain bone density and prevent further bone loss.

 

Option D. Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium: Supplementation with oral vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) along with calcium is essential to ensure proper calcium absorption and to maintain bone health. The recommended dose of vitamin D3 is typically around 800 IU per day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are recommended for up to 5 years, not just one year, in the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

choices.text: Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg HS for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 500 mcg one tablet OD for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam ½ mg tablet HS daily

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

 

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

 

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When writing a prescription, always avoid abbreviations for dosage instructions, use clear and complete language, include leading zeros for dosages less than one, and avoid trailing zeros. The correct format ensures clarity and safety for the patient.

questions.text: Best indicator for chronic malnutrition in children is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Height for age

 

Height for age is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition in children. When height for age is low, it indicates stunting, which develops over a long period due to chronic nutritional deficiency. This is because:

 

  • Height takes a longer time to be affected by nutritional deficiency
  • Once affected, height also takes longer to recover
  • Therefore, low height for age (stunting) reflects long-term or chronic nutritional deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for age:

 

  • Indicates underweight status
  • Reflects acute on chronic malnutrition
  • Can change relatively quickly with nutritional status

 

Option B. Weight for height:

 

  • Indicates wasting
  • Reflects acute malnutrition
  • Changes rapidly with current nutritional status

 

Option D. Head circumference:

 

  • Not a primary indicator for malnutrition
  • More relevant for neurological development assessment
  • Does not specifically reflect nutritional status

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Height for age is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition in children, with low values indicating stunting, while weight for height indicates acute malnutrition (wasting) and weight for age indicates acute on chronic malnutrition (underweight).

questions.text: A woman compulsively washes her hands at least 40 times per day without any logical reason. Which of the following Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) techniques is most appropriate for her treatment? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Response Prevention

 

Explanation: 

 

Response Prevention is the most appropriate technique for treating compulsive hand washing, which is a classic symptom of OCD. In this case, the woman engages in repetitive handwashing (compulsion) likely in response to obsessive thoughts about contamination. Response Prevention involves preventing the person from performing the compulsive behavior (handwashing) when they feel the urge. This breaks the reinforcement cycle where the anxiety reduction from performing the compulsion reinforces the behavior. When used together with Exposure therapy, it forms "Exposure and Response Prevention" (ERP), which is the first-line psychotherapeutic treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

  • Option B. Exposure (Incorrect): While Exposure is an important component of treating OCD, it is typically used in conjunction with Response Prevention. Exposure alone (having the patient confront the feared contaminant) without preventing the compulsive response would not effectively treat the condition as the patient would continue to use handwashing to reduce anxiety. Hence, if we have to pick between exposure and response prevention, the response prevention becomes the better answer.
  • Option C. Thought Stopping (Incorrect): Thought stopping is a technique where the patient attempts to interrupt unwanted thoughts, often using distraction or verbal commands. While sometimes used in cognitive therapy, it's not considered highly effective for OCD treatment and is not the first-line approach for compulsive behaviors.
  • Option D. Desensitization (Incorrect): Systematic desensitization involves gradually exposing patients to anxiety-provoking stimuli while they are in a relaxed state. While useful for specific phobias, it is not the primary technique for treating compulsive behaviors in OCD. The technique doesn't address the response component of the OCD cycle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the treatment of choice for OCD, including compulsive hand washing. Response Prevention specifically targets the compulsive behavior by preventing the ritualistic response, while Exposure targets the obsessional fears. Together they break the OCD cycle of obsessions leading to anxiety, followed by compulsions that temporarily reduce anxiety but ultimately reinforce the behavior.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

  • Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. 
  • It is well known to cause gastrointestinal side effects, including diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, particularly when first starting the medication or when the dose is increased. 
  • Diarrhea is one of the most common side effects of metformin and can sometimes be severe or persistent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not commonly associated with diarrhea. Its common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analog used as an adjunct treatment for diabetes. It slows gastric emptying and promotes satiety but is not typically associated with diarrhea. Nausea is a more common gastrointestinal side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is not known to cause diarrhea. Hypoglycemia is its most significant side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, metformin is the anti-diabetic drug most commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea. The patient's symptoms are likely related to metformin use.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are not approved for treatment of (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rett syndrome

 

  • Cannabinoids, including cannabidiol (CBD), are not currently approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome. 
  • Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurological disorder, and while there is ongoing research into potential treatments, cannabinoids are not among the approved therapies for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy. It is used to reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this condition.

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: Cannabidiol (CBD) is also approved for the treatment of seizures associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). It has been shown to reduce seizure frequency in patients with TSC.

 

Option D. Lennox Gastaut syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, another severe form of epilepsy. It is used to help reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD), are not approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome, whereas they are approved for use in Dravet Syndrome, Tuberous Sclerosis, and Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent attacks of gout was started on a therapy that inhibits the synthesis of uric acid. His symptoms were relieved after therapy. Identify the drug he was prescribed? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Allopurinol

 

Allopurinol is a competitive inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme. It decreases the production of uric acid, therefore useful in cases of hyperuricemia and chronic gout.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acids. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation.

 

Option B. Colchicine: Colchicine is Inhibit granulocyte migration and the release of glycoprotein from neutrophils. Used in Gout, Cirrhosis, Acute Mediterranean Fever, Sarcoidosis.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a Non-Selective COX inhibitor having analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory property. A/E – Peptic ulcer disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allopurinol is the drug of choice for reducing uric acid synthesis in patients with chronic gout by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme. It effectively lowers serum and urinary uric acid levels, thereby preventing gout attacks.

questions.text: A patient with unilateral, unilocular suppurating bubo and a single sinus tract is observed to have a primary genital ulcer. The likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

  • Chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers accompanied by unilateral suppurative (pus-filled) inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo). 

 

 

  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen in chancroid.
  • The key connection here is the presence of both a primary genital ulcer and suppurating bubo with sinus tract formation. 
  • Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and has an incubation period of 3-5 days. 
  • The genital ulcer in chancroid is soft, tender, with necrotic base and ragged undermined edges that bleeds on touch. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum):

 

  • Incorrect because in LGV, the primary genital ulcer is transient and often goes unnoticed or has already healed by the time the bubo develops. 
  • The question explicitly mentions the presence of both the ulcer and bubo simultaneously, which is characteristic of chancroid rather than LGV.
  • LGV buboes also tend to exhibit the "groove sign" due to involvement of both inguinal and femoral nodes.

 

 

Option C. Herpes Genitalis:

 

  • Incorrect because while herpes causes painful genital ulcers (typically multiple grouped vesicles that rupture to form ulcers with polycyclic margins), it does not cause suppurative bubo formation with sinus tracts. 
  • Herpes may cause bilateral tender lymphadenopathy, but not the formation of buboes that suppurate.

 

Option D. Primary Syphilis:

 

  • Incorrect because primary syphilis causes a painless, indurated, clean-based ulcer (chancre) with non-suppurative bilateral lymphadenopathy. 
  • The lymph nodes in primary syphilis are typically described as "shotty" and do not form suppurative buboes or sinus tracts. 
  • The lymphadenopathy is also usually bilateral rather than unilateral.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The combination of a primary genital ulcer with a concurrent unilateral suppurating bubo that forms a sinus tract is highly characteristic of chancroid, distinguishing it from other sexually transmitted infections like LGV (where the primary lesion is often absent by the time buboes appear), herpes (which doesn't cause suppurative buboes), and syphilis (which causes painless, non-suppurating lymphadenopathy).

questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the following image. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II

 

  • The Salter-Harris classification system is used to describe fractures involving the growth plate (physis) in children. 
  • The types range from I to V, with increasing severity:
    • Type I: Slip or separation of the growth plate.
    • Type II: Fracture that involves a part of the metaphysis and the growth plate. This is the most common type and is also known as the Thurston-Holland sign.
    • Type III: Fracture through the growth plate and epiphysis, involving the joint surface, causing epiphyseal split.
    • Type IV: Fracture through the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis.
    • Type V: Compression/crush injury to the growth plate with initially normal x-ray.

 

 

  • In the provided image, the fracture depicted involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis, which classifies it as a Type II injury.
  • Remember: 
    • MC type is Type II.
    • Location of Epiphyseal Injuries: When it comes to epiphyseal injuries, particularly in pediatric cases, these injuries typically occur through the zone of hypertrophy of the growth plate. This zone is one of the layers of the growth plate where chondrocytes mature and enlarge before the end of the bone lengthens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option Type I: Involves only the growth plate without extending into the metaphysis or epiphysis.

 

Option Type III: Involves the growth plate and the epiphysis, extending into the joint.

 

Option Type IV: Involves the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the Type II Salter-Harris physeal injury in children.
  • A Type II Salter-Harris fracture involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis and is the most common type of growth plate fracture.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a history of hyperglycemia and has had positive urine glucose tests on two separate occasions in the last six months. The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The physician is considering various medications to manage the patient's condition and prevent potential complications, including renal involvement. Which of the following drugs will not delay renal involvement? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat hypertension. 
  • While effective at lowering blood pressure, it does not have specific renal protective effects and may not delay the progression of renal disease in diabetic patients. 
  • In fact, in some cases, thiazide diuretics can increase the risk of developing hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are a class of medications used to lower blood sugar in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by promoting glucose excretion through the urine. Importantly, SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

 

Option B. Finerenone: It is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that reduces inflammation and fibrosis in the kidneys. Clinical trials have demonstrated that finerenone can reduce the risk of kidney disease progression in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs (e.g., losartan, valsartan) are another class of medications used to manage hypertension and heart failure. Like ACE inhibitors, ARBs have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic nephropathy by reducing proteinuria and lowering intraglomerular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, while SGLT2 inhibitors, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs have renal protective properties and can help delay renal involvement in diabetic patients, hydrochlorothiazide does not have these specific protective effects and is the correct answer in this context.

questions.text: In a class trip there were 75 camper school students, of which 50 had been immunized for Measles previously. During the trip, a child developed Measles. Subsequently, upon returning home, 12 more children developed Measles. Calculate the Secondary attack rate for Measles. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50%

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is calculated using the formula: 


SAR 

 

 

  • Total students = 75
  • Previously immunized = 50 (these are immune and not susceptible)
  • Susceptible students initially = 75 - 50 = 25
  • One student developed measles first (primary case)
  • Therefore, remaining susceptibles = 24
  • Secondary cases = 12

 

Applying the formula: SAR = (12/24) × 100 = 50%

 

The primary case is excluded both from numerator and denominator as they cannot be a secondary case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is the number of cases occurring within the incubation period following exposure to a primary case, expressed as a percentage of the total number of exposed susceptible persons. The primary case should be excluded from both numerator and denominator.

choices.text: Fear of places from which escape is difficult

questions.text: All of the following may be termed as Agoraphobia, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Fear of heights

 

Explanation: 

 

Agoraphobia is specifically defined as fear of places from which escape might be difficult. The fear of heights (acrophobia) is a specific phobia and not a component of agoraphobia. Agoraphobia includes fears related to situations where escape might be challenging, embarrassing, or help may not be available if panic-like symptoms occur.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Fear of places from where escape is difficult (Incorrect): This is the core definition of agoraphobia. People with agoraphobia fear situations where they feel trapped, helpless, or embarrassed.
  • Option C. Fear of open spaces (Incorrect): This is included in the definition of agoraphobia. 
  • Option D. Fear of crowded places (Incorrect): Fear of crowded places is a characteristic manifestation of agoraphobia. Crowded places may trigger anxiety due to perceived difficulty in escaping or reaching help if needed.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Agoraphobia is characterized by fear of situations where escape might be difficult, help might not be available, or where panic attacks might occur. It commonly includes fears of open spaces, enclosed places, crowds, public transportation, and being outside alone. Specific phobias like acrophobia (fear of heights) are distinct from agoraphobia and classified separately as specific phobias.

choices.text: Presence of Circle of Hebra lesions
Scalp and face are spared in infants
Norwegian scabies is the most severe form
Burrows are found in the stratum corneum

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding scabies? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scalp and face are spared in infants

 

  • The statement that "Scalp and face are spared in infants" is incorrect regarding scabies. 
  • In infants and young children, scabies frequently involves the scalp, face, neck, and even the palms and soles.
  • This is in contrast to adults, where the head and neck are usually spared (except in crusted/Norwegian scabies). 
  • The predilection for head and face involvement in infants is an important diagnostic feature of infantile scabies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of Circle of Hebra lesions :

 

  • Circle of Hebra refers to the characteristic distribution of scabies lesions around the umbilicus in a circular pattern. 
  • This is a recognized feature of scabies and helps in clinical diagnosis.

 

Option C. Norwegian scabies is the most severe form:

 

  • Norwegian scabies (also called crusted scabies) is indeed the most severe form of scabies. 
  • It is characterized by massive hyperinfestation with thousands to millions of mites, extensive scaling, crusting, and hyperkeratosis. 

 

 

It typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals, the elderly, or those with neurological disorders.

 

Option D. Burrows are found in the stratum corneum:

 

  • The female Sarcoptes scabiei mite creates burrows specifically within the stratum corneum (the outermost layer of the epidermis). 
  • These burrows appear as thin, grayish, slightly raised, linear or curved lines and are pathognomonic for scabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unlike in adults where the head and neck are typically spared, scabies in infants and young children commonly involves the scalp, face, and neck areas, making this an important distinguishing feature for diagnosing scabies in different age groups.

questions.text: What is the most accurate description of Eczema marginatum? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tinea cruris

 

  • Eczema marginatum is another name for Tinea cruris, which is a dermatophyte infection of the groin area. 

 

 

  • It is also colloquially referred to as "jock itch" or "dhobi itch."
  • Tinea cruris presents as an annular, sharply demarcated plaque with peripheral scaling, inner aspects of the thighs. 
  • The infection expands centrifugally with central clearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea capitis:

 

  • Tinea capitis refers to a dermatophyte infection of the scalp and hair, not the groin. 
  • It typically manifests as patches of hair loss with scaling and can present as black dot, gray patch, kerion, or favus variants depending on the causative organism and host immune response.

 

Option B. Tinea barbae: 

 

  • Tinea barbae refers to a fungal infection of the beard area in men. 
  • It is not the same as Eczema marginatum, which affects the groin area. 
  • Tinea barbae involves the coarse terminal hair of the beard and can cause follicular inflammation.

 

 

Option D. Tinea unguium:

 

  • Tinea unguium refers to a dermatophyte infection of the nail plate. 

 

 

  • It presents with discoloration, thickening, and crumbling of the nail plate with subungual hyperkeratosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eczema marginatum is synonymous with Tinea cruris (fungal infection of the groin), characterized by annular, well-demarcated plaques with active margins showing scaling and inflammation, most commonly affecting the inner thighs and groin area.

questions.text: Long-term drug abuse with which of the following is associated with an increased risk of developing Schizophrenia? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Cannabis

 

Explanation: 

 

Long-term cannabis use has been associated with an increased risk of developing schizophrenia. Regular cannabis use, especially during adolescence when the brain is still developing, can significantly increase the risk of developing psychotic disorders including schizophrenia in predisposed individuals.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Barbiturates (Incorrect): While barbiturates can cause various adverse effects including dependence and cognitive impairment, they have not been specifically linked to increased risk of developing schizophrenia. 
  • Option B. Heroin (Incorrect): Heroin is an opioid that can lead to severe dependence and various health problems, but it is not specifically associated with increasing the risk of developing schizophrenia. 
  • Option D. Magic Mushrooms (Incorrect): Magic mushrooms contain psilocybin, a hallucinogen that can cause short-term psychotic-like experiences during intoxication. However, unlike cannabis, they have not been consistently linked to increased risk of developing chronic schizophrenia. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cannabis use, particularly during adolescence and young adulthood, is a recognized environmental risk factor for developing schizophrenia in vulnerable individuals. The risk appears to be dose-dependent and may involve interactions with genetic predisposition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with growth on talus as seen on foot x-ray. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

  • Osteochondroma is a common benign bone tumor that typically presents as a growth on the bone with a cartilage cap. 
  • In this case, the boy has a growth on the talus, which is characteristic of osteochondroma.
  • X-ray Findings: On x-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bone growth projecting from the surface, often with a cartilaginous cap that is not visible on the x-ray itself since cartilage is radiolucent.
  • Presentation: Patients often notice a palpable mass, which feels larger than what is seen on the x-ray due to the cartilage component (as radiolucent).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma: This is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs inside the bone (endosteal). It is more common in small bones of the hands and feet and does not present as an external growth.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: This is a malignant bone tumor typically found in the metaphyses of long bones, such as around the knee. It presents as a destructive bone lesion with a periosteal reaction, often not seen in the talus.

 

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the bone that leads to inflammation. It usually shows a solid periosteal reaction or lytic cavities on x-ray and does not present as a growth. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows growth in the talus which is characteristic of osteochondroma of the talus bone. 
  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor presenting as a palpable growth with a cartilaginous cap, most often found in young adults, and visible on x-ray as a bony projection.

questions.text: Patient had a fall on Outstretched hand. He presented with Fracture and displacement of Base of 1st metacarpal. This fracture is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bennet’s fracture 

 

  • A Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone, which is associated with displacement due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle. 

 

 

  • This type of fracture typically occurs when a person falls on an outstretched hand (FOOSH injury). 
  • The mechanism of injury and the specific displacement due to muscle pull are characteristic of Bennett's fracture.
  • The shaft of the metacarpal is laterally dislocated by the unopposedpull of the abductor pollicis longus. 
  • The medial projection of the metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches remains in place. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scaphoid fracture: A scaphoid fracture is common in young adults after a fall on an outstretched hand, but it involves the scaphoid bone in the wrist, not the base of the first metacarpal.

 

 

Option C. Rolando fracture: This is also an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal (T or Y) but involves comminution without displacement.

 

 

Option D. Colles fracture: A Colles' fracture is a distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement, commonly seen in older adults after a fall on an outstretched hand, but it does not involve the first metacarpal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal with displacement due to muscle pull, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand.

choices.text: Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of drug dependence? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Use of illegal substances

 

Explanation: 

 

Use of illegal substances is not a diagnostic feature of drug dependence. Drug dependence is defined by specific psychological and physiological features related to substance use patterns and their effects, regardless of whether the substance is legal or illegal. Dependence can develop to legal substances (such as alcohol, prescription medications) just as it can to illegal substances.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Tolerance (Incorrect): Tolerance is a core feature of drug dependence, defined as "increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect." As the body adapts to the presence of the substance, more is needed to achieve the same psychoactive effects, which is a hallmark sign of dependence.
  • Option B. Persistent desire to quit drug (Incorrect): A persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use is a recognized feature of dependence. This represents the loss of control aspect of addiction, where individuals recognize the problems caused by their substance use but struggle to stop despite their intentions.
  • Option C. Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period (Incorrect): Taking the substance in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended is a characteristic feature of dependence. This reflects the impaired control over substance use that defines dependence.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dependence is characterised by a strong drive to use the substance, as manifested by 

  1. Tolerance- Increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect 
  2. Withdrawal symptoms: Typical symptoms that develop when the substance intake is reduced or stopped.
  3. Craving- Strong desire or urge to use the substance
  4. Inability to control substance taking behaviour in terms of its onset, termination or levels of use.
  5. Continued use of a substance despite clear harmful consequences.
  6. Progressive neglect of other interests because of substance use.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epinephrine

 

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

 

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are:

 

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

 

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon primarily works to increase blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It does not play a significant role in shifting potassium intracellularly.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks muscarinic receptors. It is not involved in potassium homeostasis or its intracellular movement.

 

Option D. Lactic acid: Lactic acid does not facilitate the intracellular movement of potassium. In fact, metabolic acidosis (which can be associated with elevated lactic acid levels) tends to cause potassium to move out of cells into the extracellular space, exacerbating hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 agonists, such as Epinephrine, are effective in promoting the intracellular movement of potassium, thereby reducing serum potassium levels in cases of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A patient was started on antihypertensive drugs. Few days later, the patient presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

 

The given picture is suggestive of angioedema. The antihypertensive drug that can lead to the development of angioedema is ACE-Inhibitors – Lisinopril in the given option. Angioedema caused by ACE inhibitors is a class effect, and patients who experience this side effect should not be given any other ACE inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. It can cause side effects such as headache, flushing, and peripheral edema, but it is not typically associated with angioedema.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker used to treat hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions. Its common side effects include bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities, but it does not cause angioedema.

 

Option D. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It can cause side effects such as dry mouth, sedation, and rebound hypertension upon abrupt withdrawal, but it is not associated with angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:-

 

  • Angioedema
  • Cough
  • Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: A woman at 8 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propylthiouracil

 

During the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism. This preference is due to the fact that PTU has a lower risk of causing birth defects compared to Methimazole, which is associated with a rare but serious condition called aplasia cutis (a congenital skin defect). PTU is considered safer in early pregnancy, especially during organogenesis (the first trimester), as it crosses the placenta less readily than Methimazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methimazole: Methimazole is typically avoided during the first trimester because it is associated with teratogenic effects, particularly the risk of aplasia cutis and other congenital abnormalities.

 

Option B. Carbimazole: Carbimazole is a prodrug that is converted to Methimazole in the body. Like Methimazole, it is also avoided during the first trimester due to the risk of congenital defects.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine: Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnancy at any stage, as it can destroy fetal thyroid tissue, leading to permanent hypothyroidism in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism due to its lower risk of causing birth defects compared to other antithyroid medications.

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This is due to inhibition of_____ by aspirin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboxane Synthesis

 

Thromboxane A2 is a substance that promotes platelet aggregation and also causes vasoconstriction. Aspirin inhibits the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is crucial for the synthesis of thromboxane A2. By inhibiting thromboxane synthesis, aspirin reduces platelet aggregation, which can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, manifesting as occult blood in the stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phospholipase A2: This enzyme is involved in the initial step of arachidonic acid release from cell membranes, but it is not directly inhibited by aspirin. The effect of aspirin is more downstream in the arachidonic acid pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Phospholipase C is involved in intracellular signaling but is not inhibited by aspirin. It does not play a direct role in the mechanism by which aspirin may cause occult blood in the stool.

 

Option D. Phospholipase D: Similar to Phospholipase C, Phospholipase D is not inhibited by aspirin and is not involved in the mechanism leading to gastrointestinal bleeding from aspirin use.

 

Therefore, in this patient, the occult blood in the stool is most likely due to the inhibition of thromboxane synthesis by aspirin, making option B the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin inhibits thromboxane synthesis by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), leading to reduced platelet aggregation and an increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for the same since a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea, and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

The drug that is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects is amiodarone.

 

Amiodarone

 

→ Longest acting [t1/2 → > 3 weeks] anti-arrhythmic drug

 

→ MOA →

  1. Na+ channel Blocker
  2. β-Blocker (Non-competitive)
  3. K+ channel Blocker [Main action]
  4. Calcium channel blocker

 

→ Indicated in all arrhythmias except Torsades de pointes

 

→ Adverse effect of amiodarone:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a Selective Beta 1 Blocker. C/I in Bradycardia, AV Block and Acute CHF. It is used in HTN, Classical angina, MI, Chronic CHF, Arrythmia

 

Option C. Aspirin: Aspirin is only irreversible COX Inhibitor, anti-platelet drug. C/I in child with viral infection (Due to Reye’s syndrome). Can cause Hyperuricemia at therapeutic doses - avoid in gout

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is classified under potassium-sparing diuretic. Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains the body's potassium levels. C/I in patients with hyperkalemia. Can cause gynecomastia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is associated with a range of serious side effects, including pulmonary fibrosis, thyroid dysfunction, liver toxicity, and photosensitivity.

questions.text: Name the drug that acts on both the marked points: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omapatrilat

 

Omapatrilat is a inhibits both neprilysin and Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). As a result, there is a decrease in Angiotensin II and increase in natriuretic peptide levels, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacubitril: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin reducing breakdown of vasoactive peptides such as natriuretic peptides and bradykinin, therefore increasing their levels leading to vasodilation, diuresis, and counteracting the effects of RAAS. Sacubitril is combined with an ARB, valsartan is indicated for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Option C. Losartan: Losartan is classified under angiotensin receptor blocker, used in the treatment of hypertension. A/E are Hyperkalemia, Dysgeusia, Postural hypotension. C/I in pregnancy, B/L Renal Artery Stenosis. Losartan decreases serum uric acid levels.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a synthetic brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), acts as a natriuretic and vasodilator. Primarily used in acute decompensated heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omapatrilat inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme, thereby decreasing angiotensin II and increasing natriuretic peptides, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

choices.text: Osteoporosis is a relative contraindication for ECT.
Benzodiazepines should be discontinued prior to ECT.
The most common complication is Amnesia.
Increased intracranial pressure is an absolute contraindication for ECT.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Increased intracranial pressure is a contraindication for ECT.

 

Explanation: 

 

According to current understanding, there are no absolute contraindications for ECT. 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Osteoporosis is a relative contraindication for ECT (Correct): Osteoporosis is indeed a relative contraindication for ECT because the muscle contractions during the seizure could potentially cause fractures in patients with severe osteoporosis. However, with modern modified ECT using muscle relaxants, this risk is significantly reduced.
  • Option B. Benzodiazepines should be discontinued prior to ECT (Correct): Benzodiazepines should be discontinued before ECT because they have anticonvulsant properties that can raise the seizure threshold and potentially interfere with the therapeutic efficacy of ECT by reducing seizure duration.
  • Option C. The most common complication is Amnesia (Correct): Memory disturbances, particularly retrograde amnesia, are the most common side effects of ECT. Retrograde amnesia is more common than anterograde amnesia, and recovery typically occurs within 1-6 months.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While ECT requires careful consideration of patient-specific factors, there are no absolute contraindications for its use. Earlier, raised intracranial pressure was considered an absolute contraindication for ECT, but no longer. The main side effect is memory disturbance, particularly retrograde amnesia, which is usually temporary. Modern modified ECT using anaesthesia and muscle relaxants has significantly improved the safety profile of this effective treatment for severe depression, catatonia, and certain other psychiatric conditions.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. What is the reason behind this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rebound hypertension

 

Clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist and a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. Used in HTN. Stimulates presynaptic α-receptor in the vasomotor centre in the brainstem, suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.

 

Clonidine sudden stoppage causes Rebound HTN and sympathetic overactivity.

 

Treatment of clonidine withdrawal is Phentolamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postural Hypotension

 

  • Description: A condition where blood pressure drops significantly upon standing up.
  • Relevance: Clonidine can cause postural hypotension, but sudden discontinuation leads to rebound hypertension, not postural hypotension.

 

Option B. Receptor Upregulation

 

  • Description: An increase in the number of receptors on the cell surface.
  • Relevance: This concept is more related to long-term exposure to antagonists, not the sudden withdrawal of an agonist like clonidine.

 

Option D. Receptor Hypersensitivity

 

  • Description: Increased sensitivity of receptors to a stimulus.
  • Relevance: While receptor hypersensitivity can occur, it is not the primary mechanism behind the headache and rebound hypertension seen with sudden clonidine withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rebound hypertension is a critical condition that can occur when clonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, is suddenly discontinued. This results in a rapid increase in sympathetic activity, leading to symptoms such as headache due to a sudden spike in blood pressure.

choices.text: Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is un-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is non-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor
Drug A is un-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the drugs shown in graph A and graph B is correct. (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

 

To determine the correct answer, let's analyze the Lineweaver-Burk plots and the types of enzyme inhibition they represent:

 

For non-competitive inhibitors, the lines intersect at the x-axis. This type of inhibitor decreases VmaxVmax​ without affecting KmKm​.

 

Option A. Competitive Inhibition: On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibitors intersect with the no-inhibitor line at the y-axis. This is because competitive inhibitors increase the apparent KmKm​ (Michaelis constant) without affecting VmaxVmax​ (maximum velocity).

 

Option C. Uncompetitive Inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors result in parallel lines on the Lineweaver-Burk plot. They decrease both VmaxVmax​ and KmKm​ proportionally. 

 

Given the descriptions of the graphs:

 

  • Graph A: The lines meet at the y-axis, indicating competitive inhibition.
  • Graph B: The lines start from the same point on the x-axis, indicating non-competitive inhibition.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

B. Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.text: A young female is brought to the emergency department. Attendants inform that she has consumed 100 tablets of aspirin. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

 

Aspirin poisoning (Salicylism)

 

Respiratory Center Stimulation

↓

Hyperventilation

↓

↓CO2

↓

Respiratory Alkalosis → Reversible

↓

Metabolic Acidosis → Irreversible

 

Treatment - DOC is sodium bicarbonate (NaHC03)

  •  Reverses metabolic acidosis
  •  Helps in aspirin excretion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores: N-acetyl cysteine is an antidote for paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option B. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is useful in organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option C. Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia: Glucagon is antidote in beta-blocker toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium Bicarbonate is the treatment of choice in aspirin poisoning, as it helps to alkalize the urine and enhance the excretion of salicylates, while also correcting metabolic acidosis.
